Problem:
Consider a feedback system where the output \( z(t) \) is governed by the linear differential equation \( \dot{z} = Dz \) with an initial input \( z_0 \). The system undergoes a transformation \( h(z) = \int_0^T e^{Et}z dt \), where E is a constant matrix and T is the final time.

If \( h(z) \) is applied to the system at t = 0 and \( z(t) \) evolves under \( \dot{z} = Dz \) without further intervention, will the outcome \( z(T) \) be the same as if \( z(t) \) was propagated directly from \( z_0 \) to t = T under \( \dot{z} = Dz \)?
Explanation: The transformation \( h(z) \) applies an integral operation, which affects the evolving state of \( z(t) \) by accumulating the impact of the matrix exponential \( e^{Et} \) over time. This results in a differently evolved state at time T, as the dynamics are altered by the integral transformation.
